channel.title: Need help
channel.description:
Ok before going off and saying im a noob, and all the e-insults just read the whole thing before posting something please?
Ok i play Darkquest, and since the new landscape editor was released me and another person at Darkquest have found it entertaining to work with the editor. Well ive been able to build buildings and such, and im having no problems at all except for one; how do i add npcs?
i know it involves xml editing. i can get to actually editing it, but i just dont know what each number represents, and the other person working with me on this knows how to do it, but isnt able to explain it. Thats why i am here, plus xEnt told me to ask here :)
So basically im asking for help into identifying what each number represents. Im using this as an example as it is at the top of the NpcLoc.xml <linked-list> <NPCLoc> <id>368</id> <startX>220</startX> <startY>440</startY> <minX>220</minX> <maxX>220</maxX> <minY>440</minY> <maxY>444</maxY> </NPCLoc>
If you could explain to me what each line and/or number means i would [b]greatly[/b] appreciate it. Thanks.

item.title: Need help
item.dc:creator: @xAnonymous xAnonymous
item.description:
@xAnonymous wrote:

[quote=“Jaghetermario, post:10, topic:257052”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=339424.msg2632893#msg2632893 date=1232308817]
Actually your all wrong, 7zip is a compression format, not just the program it’s self called 7zip, so technically he can say you must 7zip the file, like i would say go zip the file. Except he is wrong since he’s talking about the included compression format inside the 7zip program which is Gzip, which you need to use to compress the xml file.
[/quote]

I was just going to ask you to do that mario

xEnt Collect ur team and make a xml editor? just a suggestion.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Need help
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

[quote=“Jaghetermario, post:10, topic:257052”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=339424.msg2632893#msg2632893 date=1232308817]
Actually your all wrong, 7zip is a compression format, not just the program it’s self called 7zip, so technically he can say you must 7zip the file, like i would say go zip the file. Except he is wrong since he’s talking about the included compression format inside the 7zip program which is Gzip, which you need to use to compress the xml file.
[/quote]

xEnt Collect ur team and make a xml editor? just a suggestion.[/quote]

an XML editor? Vrunk has one. But later on NPC/Object/item support will be properly added to the editor.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

xEnt:

Actually your all wrong, 7zip is a compression format, not just the program it’s self called 7zip, so technically he can say you must 7zip the file, like i would say go zip the file. Except he is wrong since he’s talking about the included compression format inside the 7zip program which is Gzip, which you need to use to compress the xml file.

It’s a matter of being grammatically correct, not an argument over the nomenclature of the file format. I cringe at the thought of another verb being created from a piece of software, and will personally remove the tongue from anyone that utters such nonsense.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help
item.dc:creator: @lolwut69 lolwut69
item.description:
@lolwut69 wrote:

[quote=“propker, post:6, topic:257052”]Also please note u must re 7zip the xml file for it to work.[/quote]Wow, you’re really retarded. 7zip isn’t a verb, it’s a compression program. You don’t “7zip” something, you compress it. Idiot.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

Dear god, don’t turn “7zip” into a verb. “Compress” or “zip” would suffice.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help
item.dc:creator: @propker propker
item.description:
@propker wrote:

Also please note u must re 7zip the xml file for it to work.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

since im here i might as well explain it, plus it will help other people who have the same problem as you.

id - the NPC ID which you’ll find in the NPC text file included in the xml folder.
startx - the starting X point of the location on the map
stary - the same, but the Y axis. Click on a location on my editor, you’ll see coordinates (xxx, yyy)
the rest of it is the boundary, basically the radius the NPC is allowed to wander around. if you don’t want the npc to move, make minX and maxX the same as your startX, same goes with Y.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help
item.dc:creator: @propker propker
item.description:
@propker wrote:

[quote="~Kevin, post:1, topic:257052"]Ok before going off and saying im a noob, and all the e-insults just read the whole thing before posting something please?

Ok i play Darkquest, and since the new landscape editor was released me and another person at Darkquest have found it entertaining to work with the editor. Well ive been able to build buildings and such, and im having no problems at all except for one; how do i add npcs?

i know it involves xml editing. i can get to actually editing it, but i just dont know what each number represents, and the other person working with me on this knows how to do it, but isnt able to explain it. Thats why i am here, plus xEnt told me to ask here

So basically im asking for help into identifying what each number represents. Im using this as an example as it is at the top of the NpcLoc.xml


368
220
440
220
220
440
444

If you could explain to me what each line and/or number means i would greatly appreciate it. Thanks.[/quote]

id = the npc in which is being “located”
start x = x coord it will start out
start y =y coord it will start out
when u get into the minx and maxX make sure the coords u locate here work with your start x and y…

Im pro xml duh?

Read full topic

item.title: Need help
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

Pretty much self explanatory…

is an integer representing the NPC’s ID number
is the NPC’s x-coordinate
is the NPC’s y-coordinate
and are just a bounding box around the NPC that specify how far it can wander from its original position

Read full topic
